qas.question: What does the facade of Saint Denis combine pyramids with what other style arch?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Suger<b5_0/><a0_0/>, friend and confidant of the French Kings, Louis VI and Louis VII, decided in about 1137, to rebuild the great Church of Saint-Denis, attached to an abbey which was also a royal residence. He began with <a1_0><b6_0>the West Front<b6_0/><a1_0/>, reconstructing the original Carolingian façade with its single door. He designed the façade of Saint-Denis to be an echo of <a2_0><b7_0>the Roman Arch of Constantine<b7_0/><a2_0/> with its three-part division and three large portals <a3_0><b8_0>to ease the problem of congestion<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The rose window is the earliest-known example above the West portal in France. The façade combines both round arches and <a4_0><b9_0>pointed arches of the Gothic style<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
